skill.name: execution-engine-analysis
skill.description: Analyze control flow, concurrency models, and event architectures in agent frameworks. Use when (1) understanding async vs sync execution patterns, (2) classifying execution topology (DAG/FSM/Linear), (3) mapping event emission and observability hooks, (4) evaluating scalability characteristics, or (5) comparing execution models across frameworks.
skill.summary: Analyze control flow, concurrency models, and event architectures in agent frameworks. Use when (1) ...
skill.author: Dowwie

security_audit.summary: This skill contains only documentation and analysis guidance with no executable code. It provides educational content about analyzing execution engines in agent frameworks. No security risks detected.

content.user_title: Analyze Agent Execution Engines and Concurrency Models
content.value_statement: Understanding how agent frameworks execute code is critical for performance and scalability. This skill helps you analyze execution patterns, concurrency models, and event architectures to make informed architectural decisions.
actual_capabilities: Identifies async vs sync execution patterns in agent frameworks
Classifies execution topology as DAG, FSM, or linear chain
Maps event emission and observability hooks
Evaluates scalability characteristics and blocking operations
Provides structured analysis templates and output formats
limitations: Requires manual code analysis - does not automatically scan codebases
Analysis quality depends on available documentation and code access

use_cases.title: Compare execution models across frameworks
use_cases.description: Analyze async patterns, concurrency models, and scalability characteristics to choose the best framework for your needs.

use_cases.title: Identify bottlenecks in agent execution
use_cases.description: Map observability hooks and blocking operations to optimize agent performance and resource utilization.

use_cases.title: Design execution engine architecture
use_cases.description: Understand trade-offs between different concurrency models and event architectures for building scalable agent frameworks.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Execution Analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me analyze the execution engine of this agent framework. I need to understand: 1) Is it using native async, sync with wrappers, or hybrid approach? 2) What is the execution topology - DAG, FSM, or linear chain? 3) How does the event architecture work?

prompt_templates.title: Concurrency Model Comparison
prompt_templates.prompt: I have code from two different agent frameworks. Can you analyze and compare their execution engines? I need a detailed comparison of their concurrency models, execution topologies, and event architectures with specific code references.

prompt_templates.title: Scalability Assessment
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze this agent framework for scalability issues. Identify blocking operations, resource limits, and recommend the optimal concurrency approach. Also map all observability hooks and interception points.

prompt_templates.title: Execution Pattern Documentation
prompt_templates.prompt: I'm documenting an agent framework's execution engine. Using the analysis template, provide a comprehensive report covering concurrency model, execution topology, event architecture, and observability inventory with specific file references.

output_examples.input: Analyze the execution engine of LangChain's agent framework
output: Concurrency Model: Hybrid - exposes both sync (invoke) and async (ainvoke) APIs
Execution Topology: DAG - uses dependency graphs for tool chaining
Event Architecture: Callback-based with fixed hook points (on_llm_start, on_tool_end)
Observability: Pre/post hooks for LLM calls and tool execution, async-compatible
Scalability: Thread-safe with configurable rate limits, supports streaming via async generators

best_practices: Start with codebase-mapping to identify execution-related files before analysis
Use specific code examples and line references to support your findings
Consider both sync and async code paths when evaluating concurrency models
anti_patterns: Assuming all agent frameworks use the same execution model
Ignoring error handling and timeout mechanisms in scalability analysis
Focusing only on entry points without tracing through the full execution flow

faq.question: Is this skill compatible with all agent frameworks?
faq.answer: Yes, the analysis patterns work with any Python-based agent framework including LangChain, AutoGPT, CrewAI, and custom implementations.

faq.question: What information do I need to provide for analysis?
faq.answer: You need access to the framework's source code, particularly files containing execution logic, agent definitions, and callback handlers.

faq.question: Can this skill automatically scan my codebase?
faq.answer: No, this skill provides analysis guidance and templates. You need to examine the code manually or use it alongside codebase-mapping skill.

faq.question: How do I identify the execution topology?
faq.answer: Look for graph structures, state machines, or sequential chains in the code. Check for classes like Graph, Node, State, or pipeline patterns.

faq.question: What's the difference between native async and sync with wrappers?
faq.answer: Native async uses async/await throughout. Sync with wrappers exposes sync APIs but uses asyncio.run() or thread pools internally for async operations.

faq.question: How do I map observability hooks?
faq.answer: Search for callback classes, event emitters, or decorator patterns. Look for methods starting with 'on_' or containing 'callback', 'hook', or 'emitter'.
